title: Quarto Documentation Guide
text:
This guide explains how to edit, preview, render, and publish the documentation site using Quarto.



If Quarto is not installed, run:
wget https://quarto.org/download/latest/quarto-linux-amd64.deb
sudo apt install ./quarto-linux-amd64.deb
To check the installation:
quarto --version




Site content is written in .qmd files:

index.qmd: Main landing page
about.qmd: Information about the team or organisation
navigation/*.qmd: Technical documentation pages

Use standard Markdown with optional LaTeX-style math and code blocks.




To live-preview the site locally as you edit:
quarto preview
This starts a local server (usually at http://localhost:4200) and refreshes automatically when files are saved.




To build the static site into the _site/ directory:
quarto render
This creates the final HTML version of the site locally.




To deploy the site to GitHub Pages (gh-pages branch):
quarto publish gh-pages
When prompted, confirm with Y.
Live site URL:
https://prograde-systems.github.io




The following should be excluded from version control via .gitignore:
_site/
.quarto/
*.deb
Only commit source files like .qmd, .css, _quarto.yml, and assets (e.g. images, diagrams).





Quarto Docs: https://quarto.org/docs/
Markdown Reference: https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/markdown-basics.html
Math and Equations: https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/markdown-basics.html#equations

title: Navigation Algorithms
text:
Navigation Overview
This section covers sensor fusion, filtering, and guidance systems used in Prograde Systems vehicles.

title: About
text: About this site

title: Altimeter Constant Acceleration Kalman Filter
text:
Purpose of the filter: estimating vertical position, velocity, and acceleration from altimeter measurements
Context of use (e.g., onboard state estimation for a rocket launch)
Summary of the model: 1D, constant acceleration, discrete-time Kalman filter

title: Altimeter Constant Acceleration Kalman Filter
text:
Purpose of the filter: estimating vertical position, velocity, and acceleration from altimeter measurements
Context of use (e.g., onboard state estimation for a rocket launch)
Summary of the model: 1D, constant acceleration, discrete-time Kalman filter

title: Altimeter Constant Acceleration Kalman Filter
text:
2 System Model

2.1 State Vector

Description of the state components:

Position (altitude above launch site)
Velocity (vertical speed)
Acceleration (vertical acceleration)




2.2 Process Model

Assumes constant acceleration
Time-varying state transition matrix (dependent on dt)
Includes process noise applied to the acceleration component



2.3 Measurement Model

Single altimeter measurement (position only)
Altimeter bias removed using a tare procedure before flight

title: Altimeter Constant Acceleration Kalman Filter
text:
3 Filter Structure

3.1 Initialization

Zero initial state vector
Identity covariance matrix
Altimeter noise and process noise as tunable parameters
Tare buffer logic to determine launch altitude



3.2 Prediction Step

Computes time step dt from system time
Applies constant-acceleration state transition
Updates state estimate and error covariance
Uses time-dependent process noise matrix



3.3 Update Step

Waits until the tare phase completes before accepting updates
Adjusts altimeter reading relative to launch altitude
Updates estimate using Kalman gain
Uses the Joseph form to update the covariance matrix for numerical stability

title: Altimeter Constant Acceleration Kalman Filter
text:
4 Tare Mechanism

Collects a fixed number of samples before launch
Computes average to establish the zero-altitude reference (ASL)
Filters are only applied after tare is complete

title: Altimeter Constant Acceleration Kalman Filter
text:
5 Parameters and Tuning

altimeter_noise_std: defines measurement noise
process_noise_cov_acc: variance for acceleration noise
tare_sample_count: number of samples used for tare averaging

title: Altimeter Constant Acceleration Kalman Filter
text:
6 Example Usage

Description of how to integrate into a loop or system
Requirements for time input and measurement format
Notes on synchronization and timekeeping

title: Altimeter Constant Acceleration Kalman Filter
text:
7 Limitations

Assumes motion along a single vertical axis
Sensitive to poorly tuned noise parameters
Requires consistent time steps for accurate prediction

title: Altimeter Constant Acceleration Kalman Filter
text:
8 Future Improvements

Fuse additional sensors (e.g., IMU) using an Extended Kalman Filter
Automatically detect launch rather than using a fixed tare sample count
Add support for non-uniform sampling or robust noise adaptation

title: Altimeter Constant Acceleration Kalman Filter
text:
9 Appendix

9.1 Class Summary

AltimeterCAKF: main filter class

predict(time)
update(measurement)
get_process_noise_matrix(dt)




9.2 Code Snippet

Link or reference to full implementation file (e.g., GitHub repo or altimeter_cakf.py)

title: Prograde Systems
text:
Prograde Systems is an open-source, collaborative initiative focused on experimental rocketry and independent aerospace research. Our mission is to develop and share high-quality tools, designs, and knowledge that support advanced rocketry and avionics projects.
This site serves as the central hub for our documentation efforts. It includes detailed technical articles, reference materials, and development notes covering a range of topics including flight computer design, navigation and control software, and systems integration.
By publishing our work openly, we aim to create a transparent and reusable foundation for student teams, independent researchers, and contributors interested in building robust, modern rocketry systems.
